subject: Re: [junit] Re: Using Sorter
msgSnippet: Zach, A feature we re considering for JUnit 4.9 would make what you want easier: we ll be more likely to include it if we see an issue logged at github with a
messageBody:
Zach,

A feature we're considering for JUnit 4.9 would make what you want
easier: we'll be more likely to include it if we see an issue logged
at github with a lot of votes!

David

On Thu, Apr 15, 2010 at 2:19 PM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
> Zach,
>
> Sorter is really only designed well for people building test-running
> tools, not individual tests.
>
> For now, it seems that you wouldn't lost much by writing:
>
> public void testACB() {
>  doA();  // renamed from testA
>  doC();  // renamed from testC
>  doB();  // renamed from testB
> }
>
>   David Saff
>
> On Thu, Apr 15, 2010 at 9:30 AM, zach.calvert <zcalvert@...> wrote:
>> David,
>> Can you point me in the right direction to documentation on using Sorter?  I have a handful of installer tests that I need to run in order on a win32 box.  I have come across the Sorter documentation at http://junit.sourceforge.net/javadoc_40/org/junit/runner/manipulation/Sorter.html, but it really doesn't explain how to use it.  I don't see any annotations, and I don't know what's the best practice to extend Suite and set the comparator.
>>
>> How do I use sorter so I can run testA() testC() and testB() in that order?
>>
>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
>>>
>>> fedevala,
>>>
>>> The Sorter class is there to allow you to affect the order in which
>>> tests are run.  It's first use was for things like the "run failed
>>> tests first" functionality in Eclipse, but there are other meanings of
>>> "specifying the order of tests" that it doesn't handle.  Can you
>>> describe a little more about what you're trying to do?  Thanks,
>>>
>>>    David Saff
>>>
>>> On 11/28/06, fedevela <fvela@...> wrote:
>>> > Hello,
>>> >
>>> > I decided to go with JUnit 4 instead of TestNG.
>>> >
>>> > However i do need to specify the order of the tests. Is this what the
>>> > sorter and sortable classes are for?
>>> >
>>> > How do i get a handle on the order of the tests and/or on the
>>> > comparison  of each tests?
>>> >
>>> > Thank you.
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> > Yahoo! Groups Links
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> ------------------------------------
>>
>> Yahoo! Groups Links
>>
>>
>>
>>
>
